title: R43956
content: The Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA), enacted in 1990, provides one-time cash benefits to individuals exposed to ionizing radiation from atomic weapons testing or uranium industry work between 1942 and 1971. Administered by the Civil Division of the Department of Justice, over 30,000 claims totaling nearly $2 billion have been approved, with the majority related to atomic weapons testing. The Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA) program, administered by the Department of Justice, has approved over 30,000 claims totaling nearly $2 billion in benefits. Most claims are related to atomic weapons testing. The program will sunset on July 10, 2022, and all benefit applications must be filed before that date. On July 16, 1945, the US conducted the first atomic bomb test at Trinity Test Site in New Mexico, leading to further atomic weapons testing until 1992. The majority of the 1,054 tests were done at the Nevada Test Site, with 828 underground and 100 atmospheric tests releasing radioactive material into the atmosphere. Between 1951 and 1962, the Nevada Test Site conducted 100 atmospheric atomic weapons tests, releasing radioactive material into the atmosphere. The largest test, the Hood Test in 1957, had an energy yield equivalent to 74,000 tons of TNT. Participants present at the test site during these tests may be eligible for benefits under the RECA program. The RECA program offers benefits to onsite participants, downwinders, and uranium workers affected by atomic weapons testing.
